I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of China  (PRC)  requested  a  policy  and 
advisory technical assistance (TA)1 to strengthen the PRC’s capacity to manage uncontrolled 
landfills. 2 ADB undertook a reconnaissance mission in June 2012 and reached agreement with 
the Ministry of Housing and Urban–Rural Development (MOHURD) on TA impact, outcome, 
outputs, cost and financing, implementation arrangements, and outline terms of reference for 
consulting services. 3 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Sustained economic growth in the PRC since the start of economic reform in 1978 has 
brought rapid urbanization. The urban population grew from 160 million in 1975 to 670 million in 
2010. Continuing urbanization will remain an essential pillar of growth and development in the 
PRC, but it poses a variety of environmental challenges. A major challenge is the rapid increase 
in  municipal  solid  waste  (MSW)  caused  by  population  growth  and  increasing  resource 
consumption per capita. No other country has experienced MSW quantity expansion as great or 
as rapid as the PRC has faced in the last 25 years, increasing by 4% per annum. In 2010, the 
PRC generated 157 million tons of MSW, or a quarter of the world total.4  
 
3.  The formal management of MSW in the PRC started only in the late 1980s. Prior to the 
Eighth Five-Year Plan, 1991–1995, most MSW went into dumps managed with very limited 
formal engineering standards or none at all.5 The situation has improved greatly since 1995, 
after  which  sanitary  waste  disposal  capacity  significantly  increased  in  response  to  the 
enactment of the first legislation on MSW management: the Act of Prevention and Control of 
Solid  Waste  Pollution  to  the  Environment,  1995. 6 During  the  9th  plan,  1996–2000,  the 
percentage of MSW disposed of in sanitary facilities increased from 40% to 50%. The sanitary 
disposal of MSW has remained an important target of subsequent 5-year plans. By the end of 
the 11th plan, 2006–2010, cities’ and counties’ capacity to collect and dispose of MSW had 
reached 221 million tons per year. However, this failed to keep pace with the quantity of MSW 
produced, and the proportion of MSW safely handled had reached only 64% by the end of 
2010.7 More than 60 million tons of MSW is inadequately disposed of each year, ending up in 
uncontrolled landfills.   
 
4.  The disposal of solid waste in uncontrolled landfills has created serious environmental 
concerns. The government estimates that several thousand uncontrolled landfills exist in or near 
major cities and towns in the PRC.8 These sites occupy land that could be better used, hinder 
urban development, contaminate groundwater and soil, and produce greenhouse gases and

5.  The government is aware of the problems and risks associated with current waste-
disposal practices and the legacy of uncontrolled landfills. To combat these problems, the 
government  has  passed  laws  to  protect  the  environment  from  landfill  contamination.  The 
problem is prominently addressed in the Master Plan for National Urban Domestic Solid Waste 
Treatment Facilities, 2012–2015 under the Twelfth Five-Year Plan, 2011–2015. Among other 
tasks, the plan targets the rehabilitation and securing of 1,882 uncontrolled landfills in or near 
major cities and towns at a cost of CNY21.1 billion to 2015.10 The plan prioritizes rehabilitating 
sites that hinder urban development at the urban–rural fringe or pose important risks to water 
resources. The plan highlights the need to control landfill rehabilitation taking into account local 
conditions, capacity, and needs. However, the necessary technical knowledge and financial, 
institutional, and regulatory frameworks are still underdeveloped in the PRC.  
 
6.  To address these shortcomings and work toward achieving the goals set under the 
master  plan,  the  government  requested  TA  to  strengthen  the  PRC’s  capacity  to  manage 
heretofore uncontrolled landfills. TA preparation reflects extensive consultations with MOHURD 
and other key stakeholders. MOHURD will coordinate this initiative along with parallel activities 
under the master plan. 
 
7.  The TA is consistent with the Twelfth Five-Year Plan and will support the implementation 
of the master plan. It aligns with ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC, 2011–2015, 
which  assigns  high  priority  to  strengthening  the  protection  of  land  and  water  resources, 
improving waste management toward mitigating climate change, and developing livable and 
low-carbon  cities. 11By  promoting  environmentally  sustainable  growth  and  tackling  MSW 
management, the TA also aligns with ADB’s Strategy 2020 and the draft urban operational 
plan.12 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The  impact  will  be  strengthened  policy  and  regulatory  frameworks  and  improved 
institutional capacity to rehabilitate uncontrolled landfills for sanitary MSW disposal in the PRC. 
The outcome will be agreed recommendations and guidelines to improve the management of 
uncontrolled landfills. This will be achieved by helping the government (i) to develop technical 
guidelines  on  landfill  remediation  (including  clean-up  or  containment),  land  reuse  and

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will have four outputs: (i) a review of uncontrolled landfill management in the 
PRC; (ii) technical guidelines for remediating uncontrolled landfills, including guidelines for (a) 
investigating  sites  and  assessing  their  risks,  (b)  selecting  remediation  options  regarding 
institutional control and containment and clean-up technologies, (c) planning the implementation 
of remediation, (d) planning environment management, and (e) planning post-remediation site 
redevelopment, land reuse, monitoring, and supervision; (iii) recommendations for a national 
framework for managing uncontrolled landfills, including adjustments to financial, institutional, 
and regulatory frameworks; and (iv) developing a strategy to disseminate TA findings. 13 
 
10.  The TA will be implemented in three phases. Phase 1 (3 months) will (i) review current 
waste disposal practices in the PRC;14 (ii) review existing legal and policy frameworks in the 
PRC and existing national, provincial, and municipal institutional structures for remediating 
uncontrolled landfills, which will include planning policies toward and technical methods of 
rehabilitating and redeveloping uncontrolled landfills and determining the potential long-term 
liabilities of parties involved; (iii) provide an overview of international best practice relevant to 
the PRC for managing uncontrolled landfills, including legal, policy, and planning frameworks 
and methodologies to characterize risks and assess and remediate sites; (iv) prepare an outline 
of  technical  guidelines  for  remediating  uncontrolled  landfills,  including  investigating  sites, 
assessing risk, remediation, monitoring and supervision, and redevelopment; and (v) organize a 
stakeholders’ workshop at the end of this phase to discuss the outline technical guidelines. 
 
11.  Phase 2 (7 months) will (i) draft technical guidelines for uncontrolled landfill remediation; 
(ii)  prepare  five  pilot  studies  in  selected  municipalities  to  assess  the  seriousness  of 
contamination and environmental and public health risks at uncontrolled landfills and to test and 
validate  the  draft  guidelines  for  investigating  sites  and  assessing  risks;  (iii)  organize  an 
international study tour on which five government staffers will obtain further guidance toward 
developing  the  proposed  framework;  (iv)  evaluate  potential  financing  mechanisms  for 
uncontrolled landfill remediation; (v) recommend necessary adjustments to financial, legislative, 
and regulatory frameworks; and (vi) organize a workshop to discuss the findings of the field 
validation and the policy recommendations and draft technical guidelines. 
 
12.  Phase 3 (4 months) will (i) finalize the draft technical guidelines for site investigation, risk 
assessment, and remediation to be submitted to MOHURD and (ii) develop a strategy for 
knowledge dissemination that will include (a) participation at national conferences and technical 
symposiums, (b) organizing an international symposium to share findings and experiences, and 
(c) the publication of at least one policy note.   
 
13.  Major risks to the successful implementation of the TA are the (i) inadequate or delayed 
provision  of  necessary  data,  (ii)  delayed  submission  of  required  studies,  (iii)  inadequate 
performance of consultants, and (iv) inefficient dissemination of TA findings and outputs. To 
mitigate risks, the recruitment and performance of consultants will be monitored closely. The 
government  has  agreed  to  provide  all  necessary  data  in  a  timely  manner  and  adequate

14 This will include identifying key drivers of waste disposal in uncontrolled landfills and analyzing their environmental 
and socioeconomic impacts.

C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000 equivalent, of which $500,000 will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF–other  sources).  The 
government will provide counterpart support in the form of office accommodation, remuneration 
and per diem for counterpart staff, city transport, miscellaneous administration and support 
costs, and other in-kind contributions. Cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 14 months from 2 January 2013 to 28 February 2014. 
MOHURD will be the executing and implementing agency. ADB has built a strategic partnership 
with MOHURD through a series of highly relevant and successful TA projects.15 These have 
yielded a progression of national policy frameworks and guidelines on key urban environmental 
issues facing large and medium-sized cities in the PRC, including water and wastewater tariffs, 
financing solid waste management services, and promoting wastewater reuse and beneficial 
sludge  utilization.  This  TA  will  complement  previous  TA  projects,  which  identified  the 
uncontrolled disposal of municipal solid waste and sewage sludge as an important constraint on 
sustainable urban development. MOHURD will establish a project steering committee. The 
committee  will  be  chaired  by  the  vice-director  of  the  Urban  Development  Department  of 
MOHURD and will include representatives from relevant departments of MOHURD, the Ministry 
of Environmental Protection, the Ministry of Science and Technology, and the Ministry of Land 
and Resources. 
 
16.  The TA will finance consulting services, workshops, training, field work, and survey costs. 
Consulting services totaling 32 person-months (6 person-months international and 26 person-
months national) will be required. Consultants will provide expertise in remediating landfills, 
cleaning  up contaminated  sites, managing  and  reusing  MSW, environmental  management, 
urban planning, environment economics and finance, and legislative and institutional aspects of 
environmental management.  
 
17.  Consultants will be engaged through a firm according to ADB Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) using quality- and cost-based selection 
criteria  and  simplified  technical  proposal  procedures.  A  quality–cost  weighting  of  90:10  is 
considered  appropriate  because  the  TA  is  a  multidisciplinary  assignment  that  requires

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China  for Management of Uncontrolled Landfills, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Objectives 
 
1.  The policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) includes four key outputs: (i) a review 
of uncontrolled landfill management in the People’s Republic of China (PRC); (ii) technical 
guidelines for remediating uncontrolled landfills, including guidelines for (a) investigating sites 
and  assessing  risk,  (b)  selecting  remediation  options  concerning  institutional  control  and 
containment and clean-up technologies, (c) implementing remediation, (d) planning environment 
management, and (e) planning post-remediation site redevelopment, land reuse, monitoring, 
and  supervision;  (iii)  recommendations  for  a  national  framework  for  uncontrolled  landfill 
management, including adjustments to financial, legislative, and regulatory frameworks and 
identifying possible demonstration projects; and (iv) a strategy to disseminate TA findings. The 
TA will be implemented over 14 months. 
 
B.  Tasks 
 
2.  The TA will be carried out by a consulting firm and require an estimated 32 person-
months of consulting services, 6 person-months international and 26 person-months national. 
The  final  input  of  consultants  will  be  detailed  in  the  simplified  technical  proposals  to  be 
submitted by the short-listed firms.  
 
3.  The  consultants  will  have  expertise  in  (i)  landfill  remediation;  (ii) environment  risk 
assessment, monitoring, and supervision; (iii) municipal solid waste (MSW) management and 
landfill mining; (iv) urban planning; (v) environmental economics and finance; (vi) environmental 
institutional and legal matters; and (vii) energy recovery and climate change. The indicative 
terms of reference for the experts are as follows. 
 
4.  Team  leader  and  urban  environment  management  and  landfill  remediation 
specialist  (international,  4.5  person-months,  intermittent).  The  specialist  should  have  a 
postgraduate degree related to environmental engineering and preferably specialization in MSW 
management.  The  specialist  should  also  have  over  10  years  of  work  experience  in 
environmental management and landfill remediation, having managed projects concerned with 
site contamination and landfill remediation. The specialist will be experienced in designing 
technical  guidelines  related  to  environment  management.  Previous  involvement  in  projects 
financed  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  will  be  an  advantage.  The  specialist  will  be 
responsible  for  coordinating  and  supervising  project  activities  and  outputs.  Among  other 
responsibilities, the specialist will 
(i)  prepare  a  detailed  work  plan  for  the  TA  and  ensure  that  the  team's  work 
progresses according to schedule and that TA inception, interim, draft final, and 
final  reports  and  other  outputs  are  submitted  on  time  and  are  of  a  quality 
acceptable to the Ministry of Housing and Urban–Rural Development (MOHURD) 
and ADB; 
(ii)  liaise  and  coordinate  with  MOHURD;  local,  provincial,  and  municipal 
governments; local expert institutions; and agencies involved in the TA; 
(iii)  discuss with MOHURD and interested municipalities the selection of five pilot 
sites to validate the draft guidelines for investigating sites and assessing risk; 
(iv)  review, in coordination with national and international specialists, international 
best practice relevant to the PRC for rehabilitating uncontrolled landfills; 
(v)  coordinate and lead the development of technical guidelines suitable to the PRC 
for remediating uncontrolled landfills and ensure the high quality of modules

(vii)  support the government, particularly MOHURD, in its efforts to disseminate the 
study’s findings to the State Council and other national, provincial, and municipal 
agencies; 
(viii)  support  the  government,  particularly  MOHURD,  in  identifying  possible 
demonstration projects based on TA findings; 
(ix)  organize all workshops, conferences, and symposiums and present key findings, 
i.e., draft technical guidelines and recommendations to strengthen the PRC legal 
and institutional framework and financing mechanisms; and 
(x)  support MOHURD in organizing and conducting an international symposium with 
support from ADB and potential ADB knowledge partners to present and discuss 
the findings and recommendations of the study.  
 
5.  Deputy team leader and site investigation and risk assessment specialist (national, 
12 person-months). The specialist should have a postgraduate degree related to environmental 
engineering or environmental sciences and should have over 8 years of work experience in 
managing  contaminated  sites  or  a  related  area,  experience  managing  projects  on  site 
contamination management and remediation, and experience in national project implementation 
and management. The specialist will be responsible for day-to-day liaison with MOHURD and 
other national government agencies supporting related works. Among other responsibilities, the 
specialist will 
(i)  collaborate with other consultants, both international and national, and coordinate 
with the executing agency, other government agencies, and ADB; 
(ii)  assist  the  team  leader  in  preparing  a  detailed  work  plan  for  the  TA  and 
developing a strategic planning framework and procedure suitable to the PRC for 
remediating uncontrolled landfills;   
(iii)  review PRC practices and related environmental and socioeconomic problems of  
uncontrolled MSW dump sites; 
(iv)  review  international  best  practice  and  methods  for  investigating  uncontrolled 
landfills  and  contaminated  sites,  assessing  risk,  conducting  pre-  and  post-
remediation monitoring and supervision, establishing clean-up targets for land 
reuse, and ensuring remediation works acceptance; 
(v)  prepare detailed technical guidelines for assessing uncontrolled MSW dump sites, 
including investigating sites and assessing risk; 
(vi)  coordinate the field validation of the technical guidelines for investigating sites 
and  assessing  risk  at  five  pilot  sites,  review  the  investigation  plans  and 
implementation  arrangements,  ensure  quality  control,  and  provide  on-site 
guidance and supervision during the site investigations;   
(vii)  assess in a report current practices and problems of uncontrolled MSW dump 
sites in the PRC; 
(viii)  draft guidelines for remediation work supervision and acceptance, including post-
remediation monitoring and supervision, to be a module of technical guidelines;  
(ix)  assist the team leader in (a) preparing TA inception, interim, draft final, and final 
reports  and  revising  chapters  and  sections  as  necessary  to  ensure  that  TA 
outputs  are  adequate  in  scope  and  quality;  (b)  supporting  the  government, 
particularly MOHURD, in its efforts to disseminate the study’s findings to the 
State Council and other national, provincial, and municipal agencies; and (c)

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
organizing a stakeholders workshop and presenting the draft technical guidelines 
and recommendations to strengthen the PRC legal and institutional framework 
and financing mechanisms;  
(x)  participate in national workshops and seminars and give presentations at them; 
and 
(xi)  support MOHURD in organizing and conducting an international symposium with 
support from ADB and potential ADB knowledge partners to present and discuss 
the findings and recommendations of the study.  
 
6.  Landfill remediation specialist (national, 7 person-months, intermittent). The specialist 
should have a postgraduate degree related to environmental engineering and preferably a 
specialization in MSW management. The specialist should also have over 10 years of work 
experience in landfill closure, confinement, and clean-up. The specialist will be familiar with 
PRC policies and regulations related to MSW management, landfill engineering, and waste 
reuse. Among other responsibilities, the specialist will 
(i)  review management and engineering approaches currently applied in the PRC 
for  landfill remediation;  
(ii)  assess  international  best  management  practices  and  technologies  for 
uncontrolled landfill closure, confinement, and site clean-up;  
(iii)  summarize management and technological options for uncontrolled landfills that 
may be applicable in the PRC based on tasks (i) and (ii) (the description will 
include applicability, operating principles, institutional implications, strengths and 
limitations, capital costs, and supervision and monitoring costs); 
(iv)  develop  executive  guidelines,  as  a  module  of  the  technical  guidelines,  for 
selecting remediation options, covering institutional control, engineering control 
(i.e., containment), in-situ and ex-situ clean-up, and site remediation, accounting 
for identified risks, remediation objectives, future land use, and costs;  
(v)  assist  the  executing  agency  and  local  authorities  in  identifying  suitable 
remediation  options  for  the  selected  pilots  in  collaboration  with  the  other 
international and national specialists; 
(vi)  assist the team leader in preparing TA inception, interim, draft final, and final 
reports, and conduct related work assigned by the team leader or deputy team 
leader; and 
(vii)  participate in national workshops and present project outputs. 
 
7.  Environmental law and institutional capacity building specialist (national, 4 person-
months). The specialist should have a postgraduate degree related to environmental law and 
over 5 years of experience in environmental law and institutional capacity building. Among other 
responsibilities, the specialist will 
(i)  review international experience and best practice regarding legal and institutional  
aspects of remediating uncontrolled landfills;  
(ii)  review and assess the legal framework for managing unregulated landfills in the 
PRC, including (a) reviewing national and provincial regulations and laws, (b) 
identifying  the  legal  implications  of  public  investments  in  rehabilitating  and 
redeveloping  unregulated  dump  sites,  (c)  identifying  the potential  long-term 
liabilities  of  parties  involved  in  clean-up  and  redevelopment;  (d)  researching 
national and provincial liability insurance policies, and (e) researching regulations 
that restrict site redevelopment and reuse; 
(iii)  review  and  assess  the  institutional  framework  for  the  management  of 
uncontrolled landfills in the PRC, including reviewing the existing responsibilities

Appendix 3  13 
and capacities of national, provincial, and municipal institutions regarding the 
rehabilitation, supervision, and monitoring of uncontrolled dump sites;  
(iv)  assess the capacity-building needs of national, provincial, and city institutions 
based  on  interviews  with  national  and  provincial  management  officials  and 
experts,  and support  MOHURD  in  drafting  an institutional  strengthening  and 
training program;  
(v)  support MOHURD in developing a supervision system that can be implemented 
at the national, provincial, and city level to register uncontrolled dump sites and 
monitor rehabilitation works; 
(vi)  recommend  changes  in  institutional  structures  and  responsibilities  among 
national, provincial, and city agencies regarding the management, rehabilitation, 
and redevelopment of uncontrolled landfills; 
(vii)  prepare,  as  a  module  for  the  technical  guidelines,  an  overview  of  the  PRC 
legislative,  policy,  and  institutional  framework  for  rehabilitating  uncontrolled 
landfills, describing all relevant national policies, laws, regulations and standards, 
and an overview of institutional responsibilities for planning, implementing, and 
supervising landfill remediation projects; 
(viii)  assist the team leader in preparing TA inception, interim, draft final, and final 
reports, and conduct related work assigned by the team leader or deputy team 
leader; and   
(ix)  participate in national workshops and the international symposium and present 
project outputs. 
 
8.  Environmental economics and finance specialist (national, 3 person-months). The 
specialist should have a postgraduate degree related to environmental economics and finance 
and over 5 years of work experience in the field. Among other responsibilities, the specialist will 
(i)  review international experience and best practice on financing mechanisms for 
remediating uncontrolled landfills;   
(ii)  review and assess the financing mechanisms applied in the PRC for remediating 
uncontrolled landfills and existing provincial and national funds for remediation;  
(iii)  assess the economic costs of uncontrolled municipal waste landfills in the PRC, 
and the capital and maintenance costs of landfill remediation; 
(iv)  evaluate  and  formulate  recommendations  on  potential  financing  mechanisms 
suitable to the PRC context for managing unregistered contaminated landfills, 
including private sector involvement and innovative financing mechanisms that 
have been practiced in other countries (e.g., landfill mining and carbon trading);  
(v)  prepare a technical note with recommendations on environmental economics and 
financial analysis for remediating uncontrolled landfills in the PRC; 
(vi)  develop a draft methodology to determine (a) capital and maintenance costs 
associated with landfill remediation projects, (b) the projects’ market viability, and 
(c) their financial risks; 
(vii)  test the methodology in the selected pilot sites; 
(viii)  assist the team leader in preparing TA inception, interim, draft final, and final 
reports, and conduct related work assigned by the team leader or deputy team 
leader; and   
(ix)  participate in national workshops and the international symposium and present 
project outputs. 
 
9.  Landfill  mining  and  waste  reuse  specialist  (international,  1.5  person-months, 
intermittent).  The  specialist  should  have  a  postgraduate  degree  related  to  environmental 
engineering and preferably a specialization in MSW management. The specialist should also

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
have over 10 years of work experience in MSW management and landfill mining and have 
managed projects related to landfill mining. Among other responsibilities, the specialist will 
(i)  assess international best practice in mining landfills and reusing landfill waste, 
including policy and regulatory frameworks, technical standards, and engineering 
approaches; 
(ii)  review the policy and regulatory framework and current practices in the PRC 
regarding landfill mining; 
(iii)  assess the potential, limitations, and risks of landfill mining in the PRC, including 
the potential for reducing greenhouse gas emissions from mined landfills;  
(iv)  prepare a policy note with recommendations on landfill mining and waste reuse 
for local decision-makers; and 
(v)  participate in the international symposium and give a presentation. 
 
10.  The consultants will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report within 1 month of 
mobilization; (ii) an interim report submitted 6 months after the TA starts; (iii) a draft final report 
12  months  after  the  TA  starts;  and  (iv)  a  final  report  submitted  1  month  after  receiving 
comments on the draft final report from MOHURD and ADB. The consultants will submit all 
reports in English and Chinese—six copies each in Chinese and English to MOHURD, and 
three copies of the English version to ADB, including one electronic copy on a CD-ROM. The 
reports will be published in Chinese and English and made available online. The consultants will 
organize all workshops, conferences, and symposiums and present key findings, i.e., the draft 
technical  guidelines  and  recommendations  to  strengthen  the  PRC  legal  and  institutional 
framework and financing mechanisms.
